title: Demography, Sociology, Social Work and Health Economics (DSSH)
requirements: For students in PgD Clinical Gerontology or MSc Clinical Gerontology
description: Demography: 1) basic concepts; 2) population dynamics; and 3) population ageing. Sociology and social work: 1) income maintenance; 2) living arrangement and social support; 3) family and intergenerational issues; and 4) social inequalities in health. Health economics: 1) health care financing; and 2) estimating costs of diseases and disabilities.

title: Epidemiology, Biostatistics and Research Methodology (EBR)
requirements: For students in PgD Clinical Gerontology or MSc Clinical Gerontology
description: The use of epidemiology in the study of the elderly (basic principles): 1) basic statistical methods in epidemiology; 2) commonly used parameters examined in epidemiological studies in the elderly (mortality, morbidity, utilization of health services, diagnostic information, measures of disability, factors promoting health and sustaining autonomy- lifestyle, marital status, family support and social network, income, work and retirement, environmental factors, social welfare, health care organization and utilization); 3) applications to the study of health, autonomy and disability in elderly populations; and 4) population surveys. Research methodology: 1) literature search; 2) study design; 3) ethical considerations and guidelines of good practice and 4) writing up research protocols, research paper, and presentation skills.

title: Biology of Ageing and Concept of Successful Ageing and Measurements
requirements: For students in MSc or PgDip Clinical Gerontology
description: Biology of Ageing: 1) cellular aging and theories of ageing; 2) age-related physiological changes; Successful ageing: 1) concepts and definitions; 2) existing knowledge; 3) strategies to achieve successful ageing; and 4) health promotion; Evaluation 1) Quality of life measurements : principle and tools 2) Quality of life measurements : practical application 3) Psycho-social assessment tools 4) Psycho-social assessment tools (in communications) 5) Nutrition, health and evaluation

title: Services for the Older Population (SERVICES)
requirements:
For taught postgraduate students in:- 
(i) PgD Clinical Gerontology; (ii) MSc Clinical Gerontology; (iii) PgD Women's Health Studies; or 
(iv) MSc Women's Health Studies
description: Service for the older population: 1) service providers and their interaction; 2) primary, secondary and tertiary care sectors (community care, residential homes and hospitals); 3) design of living environments; 4) measuring the quality and outcomes of medical care; 5) population screening and the strategy of prevention; and 6) elderly abuse. Palliative Medicine: 1) palliation; 2) bereavement; 3) living will, assisted death and euthanasia; and 4) other ethical issues in the care of the elderly.

title: Clinical Topics
requirements: For students in MSc or PgDip Clinical Gerontology
description: Clinical Topics: 1) Common diseases in the elderly; 2) Common presentation of diseases; 3) Prescribing in the elderly; 4) Rehabilitation; 5) Physical training and pain relief in older persons; 6) ADL training and assistive devices in older persons; 7) Cognitive and behavioural training and 8) Psychogeriatric problems : dementia, depression and suicide in the elderly and other mental health problems.

title: Practical Experience
requirements: For students in PgD Clinical Gerontology or MSc Clinical Gerontology
description: Work or attachment in the care of elderly in the medical (in the broadest sense including nursing and allied health disciplines), and/or social setting, and the writing up of one case report, consisting of three hours per week over a four-month period.

title: Project Report
requirements: For students in MSc Clinical Gerontology

He/She will spend a minimum of the equivalent of one contact hour per week with the supervisor.
